results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Bedlam [computer game]. Bedlam is a top down vertical shooting scroller in a futuristic sci fi setting for one or two players simultaneously. Players pilot a vehicle shooting and dodging aliens and fighting boss ships.

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

results.title: America's Cup Challenge for Amstrad
results.creator_credit: Micro Forte Studios, US Gold Pty Ltd and Armchair Entertainment
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and manual in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
America’s Cup Challenge is a one to two player competitive sports simulation. The included manual contains a lot of information about the America’s Cup including yachting terminology, race legs, wind angles, sails and weather conditions. The player controls the crew of a racing yacht using the joystick, chosing the type of sail at the start of the race and then switching between three different modes, helmsman, sails selection and winching. As Helmsman, players control the yacht’s direction. Sail selection allows players to move the angle of the sail’s boom and the level of use of the spinnaker or genoa. The manual advises the use of a good quality robust joystick.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/arnies-americas-cup-challenge/
Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Micro Forté Pty. Ltd. for Commodore 64, published by Electronic Arts (USA) and U.S. Gold (Europe) in 1986.

results.title: Canopy
results.credit_line:
John Harvey, Saibai Island

Multi-screen installation

Commissioned by ACMI and edited by Patrick McCabe
results.brief_description: John Harvey’s multi-screen installation, Canopy, celebrates and shares First Peoples self-representation while resisting and disrupting popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood too often defined by the white gaze of non-Indigenous filmmakers.

constellations_primary.name: Canopy
constellations_primary.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

results.description:
Throughout the history of screen culture, First Peoples have been portrayed as both an exotic curiosity and stereotypically deficient due to the ‘white gaze’ wielded by non-Indigenous Australians, who often defined First Peoples representation on-screen.

Around the 1970s, First Peoples stepped behind the camera en masse to capture their own story and control their representation, using the lens to return the gaze, look back, and look at each other. While celebrating, practicing and sharing culture, this gaze continues to resist and disrupt popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood.

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. Through the imagery in my work, I’m exploring layers of being, from the individual to family, clan, culture, country and finally, to consciousness. Canopy invites audiences to still their minds and experience the work as a meditation with an open spirit and heart. It contains my home movies along with films I’ve written and directed.” – John Harvey

Around the 1970s, First Peoples stepped behind the camera en masse to capture their own story and control their representation, using the lens to return the gaze, look back, and look at each other. While celebrating, practicing and sharing culture, this gaze continues to resist and disrupt popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood.

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. Through the imagery in my work, I’m exploring layers of being, from the individual to family, clan, culture, country and finally, to consciousness. Canopy invites audiences to still their minds and experience the work as a meditation with an open spirit and heart. It contains my home movies along with films I’ve written and directed.” – John Harvey
results.credit_line_for_label:
John Harvey, Saibai Island

Multi-screen installation

Commissioned by ACMI and edited by Patrick McCabe

results.title: Untitled Goose Game
results.credit_line:
Gift of House House Pty Ltd.
Acquired in collaboration with the Museum of Applied Sciences and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.material_description: Digital videogame and archive of material relating to the creation of Untitled Goose Game
results.brief_description: Untitled Goose Game is developed by Australian developer House House. Players take on the role of an annoying goose, waddling around an old English Town to create mischief and chaos. By completing a to-do list, players gradually unlock access to more areas of the town. Untitled Goose Game received widespread acclaim since its launched in late September 2019, with critics praising its gameplay and humour. It was named the D.I.C.E. Game of the Year and received a BAFTA Games Award for Best Family and Social game in 2020. It is available for PlayStation, Xbox, Nintendo Switch, PC and Mac.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.description: It’s a lovely morning in the village and you are horrible goose. Untitled Goose Game is a slapstick-stealth-sandbox, where you are a goose let loose on an unsuspecting village. Make your way around town, from peoples’ back gardens to the high street shops to the village green, setting up pranks, stealing hats, honking a lot, and generally ruining everyone’s day.
description_for_label: Untitled Goose Game is developed by Australian developer House House. Players take on the role of an annoying goose, waddling around an old English Town to create mischief and chaos. By completing a to-do list, players gradually unlock access to more areas of the town. Untitled Goose Game received widespread acclaim since its launched in late September 2019, with critics praising its gameplay and humour. It was named the D.I.C.E. Game of the Year and received a BAFTA Games Award for Best Family and Social game in 2020. It is available for PlayStation, Xbox, Nintendo Switch, PC and Mac.

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 8 - Black & White
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 8 – Black and White was broadcast as the sixth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!” In a first for Cyberthon, if not globally this episode was an interactive TV test pilot experiment. It allowed visitors to the Lounge Café, Melbourne an opportunity to compile sequences from the Cyberthon database from a computer also networked to RMITV studio.

A selection of artworks presented were created by: Ian Haig, Adem Jaffers, Dale Nason, Steve Middleton, Attillio Gangemi, Julian Wong, Misha Hollenbach, Derek Shiel, Martine Corompt, Stuart McCormick and DJ Andrew Till (The Visitor).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 8 – Black and White is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 7 - Violet
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 7 – Indigo was broadcast as the seventh of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Third Eye ‘Ambi Jam’ (Gus Till, Ollie Olsen, Geoffrey Hales, Simon Polinski), Cyberdada (Troy Innocent & Dale Nason), Phuture (Crissie Seivers and M. Buchanan ‘Equinox Comics’), Stelarc, Theatre TV (Eliza, Mari Giambanco and Julie Turner), Space Between the Gaps (Paul Gafney), Corruption & Vice (Ju-Ann Lam), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason and Kim Bounds) and Dont Shoot The Messenger (Steve Middleton)

Cyberthon VII: Spectrum 7 – Violet is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 3 - Yellow
results.creator_credit: G-O-D/ G=enerator, O=perator, D=estroyer, Adem Jaffers and Frank Peppard
results.brief_description:
Please note, this video may potentially trigger seizures for people with photosensitive epilepsy. Viewer discretion is advised.

Cyberthon V: Spectrum Yellow was broadcast as the third of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason and Kim Bounds) Surfis (Dom Owen and Peter Bourke), Mad Club (Danny Slim, Richard Cheese & Cracko), Christopher Coe (Digital Primate), 2120 (Claude Younge Jnr) and Phuture (Crissie Sievers).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 3 - Yellow is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: G-O-D/ G=enerator, O=perator, D=estroyer, Adem Jaffers and Frank Peppard

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 3 - Yellow is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.
